Package tage.input

Interface IInputManager

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    InputManager
    public interface IInputManager
    This interface specifies the functions provided by an input manager implementation, independent of what underlying input package the input manager uses.
    An IInputManager implementation could be based for example on the open-source Java Gaming Initiative (JGI) "JInput" package (https://jinput.dev.java.net), or on the open-source "Object-oriented Input System (OIS)" package (http://sourceforge.net/projects/wgois), or on the Microsoft "DirectInput" component of DirectX -- as long as the IInputManager implementation provides all the functionality specified by this interface.
    This allows an implementation to manage and forward device input to a game application in a device handler package-independent way.
    NB: the current IInputManager interface is not package-independent; it is tied to the JInput package.

    Three types of input controllers are recognized: keyboard, mouse, and "other" (for example, gamepads, steering wheels, etc.) Controllers are collections of components, of which there are three types: Axis, Button, and Key. Each component (axis, button, or key) has a name and an identifier. The identifier associated with a component is the primary means of accessing the component's value or for associating an action with the component.

    Axis components have a single range and can hold information for motion (linear or rotational), velocity, force, or acceleration. The following Identifiers are recognized for Axis components (that is, the Identifier parameter for a given Axis component may be any of the following):

    • X, Y, or Z (horizontal, vertical, and third-dimensional axes respectively);
    • RX, RY, or RZ (rotational data)
    • SLIDER (a slider or mouse wheel)
    • SLIDER_ACCELERATION, SLIDER_FORCE, or SLIDER_VELOCITY (respective physics attributes for the SLIDER axis)
    • X_ACCELERATION, X_FORCE, or X_VELOCITY (respective physics attributes for the X axis)
    • Y_ACCELERATION, Y_FORCE, or Y_VELOCITY (respective physics attributes for the Y axis)
    • Z_ACCELERATION, Z_FORCE, or Z_VELOCITY (respective physics attributes for the Z axis)
    • RX_ACCELERATION, RX_FORCE, or RX_VELOCITY (respective physics attributes for the RX axis)
    • RY_ACCELERATION, RY_FORCE, or RY_VELOCITY (respective physics attributes for the RY axis)
    • RZ_ACCELERATION, RZ_FORCE, or RZ_VELOCITY (respective physics attributes for the RZ axis)
    • POV (axis for point-of-view control)
    Note that each of the above constants, declared in net.java.jinput.Component.Identifier.Axis, defines a different controller axis, and that not all controllers support all axes.

    Examples:

    • The Logitech "Precision" controller returns the name "Logitech(R) Precision(TM) Gamepad" and has two Axis components with Identifiers 'x' and 'y' and 10 Button components with Identifiers '0', '1', ... '9'. 'x' and 'y' are independent axes for the horizontal and vertical "D-pad" device.
    • The PDP "Afterglow" XBox controller returns the name "Afterglow Gamepad for Xbox 360 (Controller)" and has 6 Axis controllers with Identifiers 'x', 'y', 'z', 'rx', 'ry', and 'pov' and 10 Button components with Identifiers '0', '1', ... '9'.

    A list of installed controllers can be obtained by calling getControllers(), which returns an ArrayList of controllers. The components in a given controller can be obtained by calling Controller.getComponents(), which returns an array (not an ArrayList) of Components. The Identifier for a given Component can be obtained by calling Component.getIdentifier().
    A given Axis component name may be referenced by using the Axis Identifiers declared in net.java.jinput.Component.Identifier.Axis; for example, net.java.games.jinput.Component.Identifier.Axis.RX for the rotational X axis component (if such is supported by the controller).

    Author:
    John Clevenger, based on a development version by Russell Bolles

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Interface Description
      static class  IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE
      INPUT_ACTION_TYPE enumerates the possible manners in which an IAction associated with a button or key will be invoked when the button or key generates an input event.

      void update​(float time)
      update(float time) instructs the IInputManager object to update its notion of the state of all input devices about which it knows, and then to invoke any IActions associated with device components based on the IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE of the IAction.

    • Method Detail

      • update

        void update​(float time)
        update(float time) instructs the IInputManager object to update its notion of the state of all input devices about which it knows, and then to invoke any IActions associated with device components based on the IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE of the IAction.
        Parameters:
        time - - the amount of time, normally given in milliseconds, which has passed since the last call to update().

      • associateAction

        @Deprecated
IAction associateAction​(net.java.games.input.Component.Identifier component,
                        IAction action,
                        IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE actionType)
        Deprecated.
        associateAction() causes the InputManager to associate an IAction (for example, "walk forward", "fire weapon", etc) with the activation of a specific component (for example, key 'A', etc). Associating an IAction with a component causes InputManager.update(float) to automatically invoke that IAction by calling its IAction.performAction(float,net.java.games.input.Event) method based on the associated IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE.

        NOTE: this method is deprecated and is provided for backward compatibility with older versions of Sage; use associateAction(String, Component.Identifier, IAction, INPUT_ACTION_TYPE) instead. If this method is called it defaults to associating the specified IAction with the keyboard returned by getKeyboardName(); if the specified component is not an instance of Component.Identifier.Key a warning is printed and the request is ignored.

        Parameters:
        component - - identifier of the component with which the action is to be associated
        action - - the action which is to be associated with the specified component
        actionType - -- indicates when the action is to be invoked in relation to the occurrence of component events
        Returns:
        the action which was previously associated with the specified component, or null if there was no previously associated action.

      • associateAction

        IAction associateAction​(java.lang.String controllerName,
                        net.java.games.input.Component.Identifier component,
                        IAction action,
                        IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE actionType)
        associateAction() causes the IInputManager object to associate an IAction (for example, "walk forward", "fire weapon", etc) with the activation of a specific component of a specific controller. Associating an IAction with a controller and component causes update(float) to automatically invoke that IAction, by calling its IAction.performAction(float,Event) method, based on the associated IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE (for example, each time the specified component on the specified controller changes state).
        Parameters:
        controllerName - - the name of the controller, as returned by Controller.getName() with which the action is to be associated
        component - - identifier of the component with which the action is to be associated
        action - - the action which is to be associated with the specified component
        actionType - -- indicates when the action is to be invoked in relation to the occurrence of component events
        Returns:
        the action which was previously associated with the specified component, or null if there was no previously associated action.

      • associateAction

        IAction associateAction​(net.java.games.input.Controller controller,
                        net.java.games.input.Component.Identifier component,
                        IAction action,
                        IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE actionType)
        associateAction() causes the IInputManager object to associate an IAction (for example, "walk forward", "fire weapon", etc) with the activation of a specific component of a specific controller. Associating an IAction with a controller and component causes update(float) to automatically invoke that IAction, by calling its IAction.performAction(float,Event) method, based on the associated IInputManager.INPUT_ACTION_TYPE (for example, each time the specified component on the specified controller changes state).
        Parameters:
        controller - - the controller with which the action is to be associated
        component - - identifier of the component with which the action is to be associated
        action - - the action which is to be associated with the specified component
        actionType - -- indicates when the action is to be invoked in relation to the occurrence of component events
        Returns:
        the action which was previously associated with the specified component, or null if there was no previously associated action.

      • getControllers

        java.util.ArrayList<net.java.games.input.Controller> getControllers()
        getControllers() returns an ArrayList of the controllers currently recognized as attached to the execution environment. The controllers are returned in the order in which the underlying implementation (currently JInput) returns them.
        Returns:
        a list of the available device controllers

      • getKeyboardName

        java.lang.String getKeyboardName()
        Returns the name string for the Keyboard controller (if more than one keyboard is present, the first one is returned). If no keyboard controller is found, null is returned.

      • getMouseName

        java.lang.String getMouseName()
        Returns the name string for the Mouse controller (if more than one mouse is present, the first one is returned). If no mouse controller is found, null is returned.

      • getFirstGamepadName

        java.lang.String getFirstGamepadName()
        Returns the name string for the first gamepad controller. If no gamepad controller is found, null is returned.

      • getSecondGamepadName

        java.lang.String getSecondGamepadName()
        Returns the name string for the second gamepad controller (if less than two gamepad controllers are present, null is returned).

      • getControllerByName

        net.java.games.input.Controller getControllerByName​(java.lang.String name)
        Returns the Controller with the specified name, or null if no controller of the specified name is installed.

      • getKeyboardController

        net.java.games.input.Controller getKeyboardController()
        Returns the Keyboard controller (if more than one keyboard is present, the first one is returned). If no keyboard controller is found, null is returned.

      • getKeyboardController

        net.java.games.input.Controller getKeyboardController​(int n)
        Returns the nth occurrence of a keyboard Controller. If no keyboard controller is found, null is returned.
        Parameters:
        n - Occurrence number, such as 1 for first occurrence of a keyboard, or 2 for second occurrence of a keyboard.

      • getKeyboardControllerWithNComponents

        net.java.games.input.Controller getKeyboardControllerWithNComponents​(int n)
        Returns the first keyboard controller with n or more components. If no such keyboard controller is found, null is returned.
        Parameters:
        n - The minimum number of components the keyboard should have.

      • getMouseController

        net.java.games.input.Controller getMouseController()
        Returns the Mouse controller (if more than one mouse is present, the first one is returned). If no mouse controller is found, null is returned.

      • getMouseController

        net.java.games.input.Controller getMouseController​(int n)
        Returns the nth occurrence of a Mouse Controller. If no mouse controller is found, null is returned.
        Parameters:
        n - Occurrence number, such as 1 for first occurrence of a mouse, or 2 for second occurrence of a mouse.

      • printControllers

        void printControllers​(boolean printComponents)
        Prints a list of all connected controllers to the console.
        Parameters:
        printComponents - TRUE if all the components of the controller should also be printed. FALSE if not.

      • printController

        void printController​(net.java.games.input.Controller c,
                     boolean printComponents)
        Prints a specific controllers information to the console.
        Parameters:
        c - The controller whose information is to be printed.
        printComponents - TRUE if all the components of the controller should also be printed. FALSE if not.
